artist_script:
Los Gatos, California. Tuesday afternoon, just hours before a major earnings report.
HostA: Netflix's market cap is sitting at 135 billion dollars right now.
HostB: Yeah, and that's a huge drop from their 2020 highs, isn't it? They're still one of the top 30 on the S&P 500, but way behind Disney and Comcast now.
HostA: Shares are down over 30% since the start of the year, which is just brutal when you consider the S&P is up 16.5%.
HostB: And Ted Sarandos, the CEO, he’s lost nearly 2 billion dollars of his own net worth during the pandemic.
HostA: Oof. That’s gotta sting. He owns like 15% of the company, right? Built it from the ground up.
HostB: Exactly. And analysts are only expecting 155 million paid subscribers this quarter—that’s down 10 million from last quarter.
HostA: Which is way off from their own guidance. They already lost 26 million in the first half of the year.
HostB: Moody’s actually downgraded them on Monday, saying even that subscriber drop might be optimistic.
HostA: Revenues are expected to be 4.4 billion, down almost 20% from last year.
HostB: And they’re projecting a loss per share, which is a big shift from profit.
HostA: Goldman Sachs slashed their price target to 470 dollars—lowest on Wall Street.
HostB: But they’re calling it a temporary setback, you know? Even with the subscriber contraction and everything.
HostA: The average analyst target is still around 627 though, so there’s some disagreement there.
HostB: Yeah, huge gap between where it is and where some think it could go. Tough day for streaming.
